bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, April 16, 1956

div1.p: Hench requests permission to meet with Mrs. Carroll and to have some manuscripts of her late father-in-law copied. Hench explains that he wants to give James Carroll due credit in his planned book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, April 16, 1956
div1.opener:
April 16, 1956
Mrs. George S. H. Carroll
2814 Rhode Island Avenue N.E.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mrs. Carroll:
div1.p:
I was so very sorry to have missed you the last two times I was in Washington.
I think you were not feeling well at one time and had perhaps gone to be with
your sister. Unfortunately I was so busy that I could not spend the time
locating your sister. I phoned your home but got no answer.

Mrs. Carroll, the time has come for me to close my books, so to speak, and
start writing the book on the conquest of yellow fever and about the only
unexplored sources of information are those which you so kindly let me look
over briefly. You were very kind in suggesting that the next time I came to
Washington I could have the important material photostated and that is what
I would now like to make arrangements to do.

I must give two lectures at Johns Hopkins Medical School at Baltimore on
May 9 and 10 and I am most hopeful that you will permit me to stop in Washing-
ton either the weekend of May 5 to 7 or the weekend of May 11 to 13. You and
I can pick out the material to be photostated. As a matter of fact, I think
we laid that aside in a special little bundle. Then, depending on which
you would like to have done, I can either take it, with you (if you care to
go), to the Armed Forces Department of Pathology where they have a photostat
machine and where they said they would cooperate with me; or, if you prefer,
I will arrange ahead of time to take it to a professional photostat man. It
does not take long to photostat material - perhaps less than one minute per sheet.

If you are willing to let the Armed Services Department of Pathology do it for
us, they will do it for nothing and it will be quite a saving but if, for some
reason or other, you prefer to have it done otherwise, I will make that ar-
rangement. I am so glad that you will let me do this and if you wish, we
can make an extra copy so that no matter who gets the originals, you can have
an extra set. If you want more than one set, I will see that you get it at
no cost to you and of course you keep all the originals.

Now the reason I am writing in advance is that unless we do so, the photostat
man might want us to wait or he might be so busy he would have to do it later
and I am sure that you would like to have it done on the spot, quickly, and
then be able to take the material home with you. Of course if you are willing
to trust me, I could bring it home here and have it photostated at the Mayo
Mrs. George S. H. Carroll
- 2 -
April 16, 1956
Clinic, have a couple of sets made for you and mail you the whole thing by
registered mail. I did this once before with another person and returned
the material in a locked tin box and sent the key in a separate registered
envelope. In that way everything is completely safe.

I will appreciate very much your cooperation in this matter and then you
will not have me troubling you any more and I will be able to do what I
have wanted to do - to show how much Doctor Carroll did in the yellow
fever experiments and some of the material that you have will be so very
helpful in doing that.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: I heard that you decided not to have the operation. I do hope your
arthritis has not become more active. There are one or two new cortisone
preparations that appear to be very useful. Remember, if I can help you
through your doctor, I shall be glad to do so.
(Dictated by Doctor Hench but signed by secretary in his absence.)
